criteria: Understanding Measures of Center (Mean, Median, Mode)
Understanding Measures of Variability (Range, IQR, Standard Deviation)
descriptions: Student demonstrates no understanding of measures of center.
Student can identify measures of center but struggles to apply them.
Student can calculate measures of center for a single dataset but not compare two.
Student can calculate and compare measures of center for two datasets, but the interpretation is superficial.
Student effectively uses measures of center to compare two datasets and draws reasonable inferences.
Student demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of measures of center, using them to draw insightful and nuanced comparative inferences about two populations.
Student demonstrates no understanding of measures of variability.
Student can identify measures of variability but struggles to apply them.
Student can calculate measures of variability for a single dataset but not compare two.
Student can calculate and compare measures of variability for two datasets, but the interpretation is superficial.
Student effectively uses measures of variability to compare two datasets and draws reasonable inferences.
Student demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of measures of variability, using them to draw insightful and nuanced comparative inferences about two populations.
Student is unable to draw any comparative inferences from the data.
Student attempts to draw inferences but they are not supported by the data or are illogical.
Student draws basic comparative inferences based on a single measure (either center or variability).
Student draws comparative inferences considering both measures of center and variability, but the reasoning is not always clear.
Student draws well-supported comparative inferences based on both measures of center and variability, providing clear reasoning.
Student draws insightful and nuanced comparative inferences, acknowledging limitations of the data and potential biases.
Student does not understand the concept of random samples or their importance.
Student shows some awareness of random samples but does not understand their significance in drawing inferences.
Student applies measures of center and variability to random samples but doesn't connect it to the population.
Student connects the analysis of random samples to the populations from which they were drawn, but the explanation is incomplete.
Student clearly explains how the analysis of random samples allows for inferences about the larger populations.
Student demonstrates a deep understanding of how random sampling allows for valid statistical inferences, addressing potential sources of error or bias.
